{{ infobox person | name = Jacqueline de Romilly | image = Jacqueline_de_Romilly_died_2010.jpg | caption = Jacqueline de Romilly | birth_date = {{birth date|1913|3|26|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Chartres]], [[France]] | death_date = {{death date and age|2010|12|18|1913|3|26|df=yes}} | death_place = [[Boulogne-Billancourt]], France | education = [[Lycée Louis-le-Grand]] | alma_mater = [[École Normale Supérieure]]
[[University of Paris]] | nationality = [[France|French]] | occupation = Writer
Professor | known for = Member of the [[Académie française]] }} '''Jacqueline Worms de Romilly''' ({{IPA-fr|ʁɔmiji|lang}}; née '''David''',[http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/afterword/2010/12/french-scholar-jacqueline-de-romilly-dies-at-97.html "French Scholar Jacqueline de Romilly Dies at 97" ''Los Angeles Times''] 20 December 2010 26 March 1913 – 18 December 2010) was a [[France|Franco]]-[[Greece|Greek]] [[philology|philologist]], [[classical scholar]] and [[fiction|fiction writer]]. She was the first woman nominated to the [[Collège de France]], and in 1988, the second woman to enter the [[Académie française]]. She is primarily known for her work on the culture and language of [[ancient Greece]], and in particular on [[Thucydides]]. ==Biography== Born in [[Chartres]], [[Eure-et-Loir]], she studied at the Lycée Molière. As a schoolgirl, she became the first female to qualify for a prize in the [[Concours général]], taking the first prize in [[Latin]] to French translation and second prize in [[Ancient Greek]] in 1930.{{cite book|last1=Webb|first1=Ruth|title=Women classical scholars : unsealing the fountain from the Renaissance to Jacqueline de Romilly' |editor-last=Wyles & Hall |contribution=Jacqueline de Romilly|date=2016|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=Oxford|isbn=9780198725206|page=377}} She then prepared for the [[École Normale Supérieure]] at the [[Lycée Louis-le-Grand]]. She entered the class of 1933 of the [[École Normale Supérieure|ENS Ulm]]. She passed the ''[[agrégation]]'' in [[Classics]] in 1936; however, because she was of Jewish ancestry, the [[Vichy government]] suspended her from her teaching duties during the [[German occupation of France during World War II|Occupation of France]].[http://www.parutions.com/pages/1-4-4-3976.html "D’origine juive, elle est suspendue de ses fonctions par le régime de Vichy en 1941."] She became a [[doctor of letters]] at the [[University of Paris]] in 1947. Her doctoral thesis, a "masterful"{{cite book|last1=Munn|first1=Mark|title=The School of History: Athens in the Age of Socrates|date=2002|publisher=University of California Press|location=Berkeley, Calif.|isbn=9780520236851|page=xi}} treatment of [[Athenian Empire|Athenian imperialism]] in Thucydides, was published as ''Thucydide et l'impérialisme athénien'', and subsequently translated into English as ''Thucydides and Athenian Imperialism''. After being a schoolteacher, she became a professor at [[Université Lille Nord de France|Lille University]] and subsequently at the [[University of Paris|Sorbonne]], between 1957 and 1973. She later was promoted to the chair of [[Greek language|Greek]] and the development of moral and political thought at the [[Collège de France]] — the first woman nominated to this prestigious institution. In 1988, she was the second woman (after [[Marguerite Yourcenar]]) to enter the [[Académie française]], being elected to Chair #7, which was previously occupied by [[André Roussin]]. In 1995, she obtained [[Greeks|Greek nationality]] and in 2000 was named as an Ambassador of Hellenism by the [[Greek Government|Greek government]]. A one-time president of the [[Association Guillaume Budé]], she remained an honorary president until her death at a hospital in [[Boulogne-Billancourt]] at the age of 97.{{Cite web|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/carnet/article/2010/12/19/jacqueline-de-romilly-helleniste-et-academicienne-est-morte_1455554_3382.html|title=Jacqueline de Romilly, helléniste et académicienne, est morte|work=Le Monde|accessdate=19 December 2010}} After having only received baptism in 1940, she fully converted to [[Maronite Church|Maronite Catholicism]] in 2008, aged 95.{{Cite web|url=http://www.la-croix.com/Jacqueline-de-Romilly-une-Athenienne-au-XXe-siecle/article/2449453/5548 |title=Dossier. Jacqueline de Romilly, une Athénienne au XXe siècle |work=La Croix |accessdate=20 December 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101224190347/http://www.la-croix.com/Jacqueline-de-Romilly-une-Athenienne-au-XXe-siecle/article/2449453/5548 |archivedate=December 24, 2010 }}{{Cite web|url=http://www.la-croix.com/Reaction-du-P.-Mansour-Labaky-/article/2449452/55352|title=Réaction du P. Mansour Labaky au décès de Jacqueline de Romilly|work=La Croix|accessdate=20 December 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101224090109/http://www.la-croix.com/Reaction-du-P.-Mansour-Labaky-/article/2449452/55352|archivedate=24 December 2010|df=}} ==Influence== De Romilly's two monographs on the ancient Greek historian [[Thucydides]] have been credited with "alter[ing] the landscape of Thucydidean scholarship"{{cite journal|last1=Lee|first1=Christine|title=(J.) De Romilly The Mind of Thucydides. Translated by Elizabeth Trapnell Rawlings. Edited and with an introduction by Hunter R. Rawlings III and Jeffrey S. Rusten. Pp. xx?+?195. Ithaca and London: Cornell University Press, 2012 (originally published as Histoire et raison chez Thucydide, 1956). Cased, US$35. |isbn=978-0-8014-5063-1 |journal=The Classical Review|date=20 March 2014|volume=64|issue=01|page=44|doi=10.1017/S0009840X13002266}} and "the beginning of a new era".{{cite book |last=Rijksbaron |first=Albert |year=2011 |title=The historical present in Thucydides: semantics and narrative function' |editor1=Lalot|editor2=Rijksbaron|editor3=Jacquinod|editor4=Buijs |contribution=Introduction |publisher=Brill |location=Leiden|page=1}} In 2002, Danish classical scholar Anders Holm Rasmussen described her views on Thucydides' ideology of empire as still "one of the most important viewpoints" with which modern scholars can engage.{{cite journal|last1=Holm Rasmussen|first1=Anders|title=Thucydides' Conception of the Peloponnesian War I. Imperialism|journal=Classica et Mediaevalia|date=2002|volume=52|page=85}} Published first in 1956, her work ''Histoire et raison chez Thucydide'' is still in print in the original French today, and was translated into English as ''The Mind of Thucydides'' after her death.{{cite web|title=The Mind of Thucydides'|url=http://www.cornellpress.cornell.edu/book/?GCOI=80140100913260&fa=author&person_id=4716|website=Cornell University Press (blurb)}}http://bmcr.brynmawr.edu/2013/2013-04-53.html De Romilly also published outside the field of [[Greek historiography]]. In recent years, the value of her work ''Time in Greek Tragedy'' has been recognized by scholars working not only on [[Greek drama]] but also on [[Aristotle]]'s [[metaphysics]] of time.{{cite book|last1=Laurent|first1=Régis|title=An introduction to Aristotle's metaphysics of time : historical research into the mythological and astronomical conceptions that preceded Aristotle's philosophy|date=2015|publisher=Villegagnons-Plaisance Editions|location=Paris|isbn=9782953384611|page=53}}{{cite book |last=Magnus |first=Erica W.|year=2016 |title=Time and Trace: Multidisciplinary Investigations of Temporality |editor1=Gross, S.|editor2=Ostovich, S. |contribution=Time, Cognition, and Attic Performance: Tracing a New Approach to Theatre History’s "Vexing Question" |publisher=Brill |location=Leiden}} In 2016, Rosie Wyles and [[Edith Hall]] edited a volume called ''Women Classical Scholars: Unsealing the Fountain from the Renaissance to Jacqueline de Romilly'', a history of pioneering women born between the Renaissance and 1913 who played significant roles in the history of classical scholarship.{{Cite book|url=https://global.oup.com/academic/product/women-classical-scholars-9780198725206?cc=gb&lang=en&|title=Women Classical Scholars: Unsealing the Fountain from the Renaissance to Jacqueline de Romilly|date=2016-10-27|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780198725206|editor-last=Wyles|editor-first=Rosie|series=Classical Presences|location=Oxford, New York|editor-last2=Hall|editor-first2=Edith}} ==Honours and awards== * Grand Cross of the [[Legion of Honour]] (2007) * Grand Cross of the [[Ordre national du Mérite]] * Commander of the [[Ordre des Palmes Académiques]] * Commander of the [[Ordre des Arts et des Lettres]] * Commander of the [[Order of the Phoenix (Greece)]] * Commander of the [[Order of Honour (Greece)]] * Elected to the [[Académie française]] (24 November 24, 1988) * First woman professor at the [[Collège de France]] (Chair: Greece and the formation of the moral and political thought) * First woman member of the [[Académie des Inscriptions et Belles-Lettres]] (1975) * President of the Academy of Inscriptions and Belles-Lettres (1987) * [[Austrian Decoration for Science and Art]] (1981){{cite web | url = http://www.parlament.gv.at/PAKT/VHG/XXIV/AB/AB_10542/imfname_251156.pdf | title = Reply to a parliamentary question | language = German | page=626 |trans-title=| format = pdf | accessdate = 22 November 2012 }} * Appointed by Greece as Ambassador of Hellenism (2000) (she had received citizenship in 1995) * Ambatielos Prize of the Académie des Inscriptions et Belles-Lettres (1948) * Croiset Prize of the [[Institut de France]] (1969) * Langlois Prize of the Académie française (1974) * Grand Prize of the Académie française (1984) * [[Onassis Prize]] (Athens, 1995) * [[Jean Ferré Prize|Daudet Prize]] for defence of the French language (2000) * Prize of the [[Hellenic Parliament|Greek Parliament]] (2008) * Foreign Honorary Member of the [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] (1988){{cite web|title=Book of Members, 1780–2010: Chapter D|url=http://www.amacad.org/publications/BookofMembers/ChapterD.pdf|publisher=American Academy of Arts and Sciences|accessdate=25 July 2014}} * Corresponding member of foreign academies: Denmark, Great Britain, Vienna, Athens, Bavaria, the Netherlands, Naples, Turin, Genoa and the United States. * [[Honorary doctorate]]s from the universities of [[University of Oxford|Oxford]], [[University of Athens|Athens]], [[University of Dublin|Dublin]], [[University of Heidelberg|Heidelberg]], [[University of Montreal|Montreal]] and [[Yale University]] ==Works published in English translation== De Romilly's work was largely published in French, but some of her works were written in or translated into English:Compiled from ''[[L'Année Philologique]]'' '''Books''' * ''Thucydides and Athenian Imperialism'', translated by P. Thody. Oxford, 1963. * ''Time in Greek Tragedy'' ([[Messenger Lectures]]). Cornell, 1968. * ''Magic and Rhetoric in Ancient Greece'' ([[Carl Newell Jackson Lectures]]). Cambridge, MA, 1975. * ''The Rise and Fall of States According to Greek Authors'' ([[Thomas Spencer Jerome Lectures]]). Ann Arbor, 1977. * ''A Short History of Greek Literature'', translated by L. Doherty. Chicago, 1985. * ''The Great Sophists in Periclean Athens'', translated by J. Lloyd. Oxford, 1991. * ''The Mind of Thucydides'', translated by E. T. Rawlings. Cornell, 2012. '''Articles''' * "Thucydides and the Cities of the Athenian Empire", in ''[[Institute of Classical Studies|BICS]]'' 13 (1966) 1-12. * "''Phoenician Women'' of Euripides: Topicality in Greek Tragedy", translated by D. H. Orrok, in ''[[Bucknell University Press#Bucknell Review|Bucknell Review]]'' 15 (1967) 108-132. * "Fairness and Kindness in Thucydides", in ''[[Phoenix (classics journal)|Phoenix]]'' 28 (1974) 95-100. * "Plato and Conjuring", in K. V. Erickson (ed.), ''Plato: True and Sophistic Rhetoric''. Amsterdam, 1979. * "Agamemnon in Doubt and Hesitation", in P. Pucci (ed.), ''Language and the Tragic Hero: Essays on Greek Tragedy in Honor of Gordon M. Kirkwood'', 25-37. Atlanta, 1988. * "Isocrates and Europe", in ''Greece & Rome'' 39 (1992) 2-13. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.academie-francaise.fr/immortels/index.html L'Académie française] {{fr icon}} {{Académie française Seat 7}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Romilly, Jacqueline de}} [[Category:1913 births]] [[Category:2010 deaths]] [[Category:People from Chartres]] [[Category:French Jews]] [[Category:French Roman Catholics]] [[Category:French Maronites]] [[Category:Collège de France faculty]] [[Category:Lycée Louis-le-Grand alumni]] [[Category:École Normale Supérieure alumni]] [[Category:École Normale Supérieure faculty]] [[Category:Members of the Académie française]] [[Category:Members of the Académie des Inscriptions et Belles-Lettres]] [[Category:Grand Croix of the Légion d'honneur]] [[Category:Grand Cross of the National Order of Merit (France)]] [[Category:Commandeurs of the Ordre des Palmes Académiques]] [[Category:Commandeurs of the Ordre des Arts et des Lettres]] [[Category:Commanders of the Order of the Phoenix (Greece)]] [[Category:Commanders of the Order of Honour (Greece)]] [[Category:Fellows of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] [[Category:Recipients of the Austrian Decoration for Science and Art]] [[Category:Historians of antiquity]] [[Category:Place of death missing]] [[Category:Jewish women writers]] [[Category:Jewish writers]] [[Category:Classical studies]] [[Category:Classical scholars]] [[Category:Women classical scholars]]

"'''Jerusalem of the West'''" was a term historically used by Jews to describe a non-Jewish city west of [[Jerusalem]] where the [[Jewish diaspora]] nonetheless enjoyed significant influence, freedom (of religion), and numbers, usually in Western Europe or [[Maghreb]]. Possibly its most persistent use was that of the [[Jews in Amsterdam|Jews of Amsterdam]]. ==Applications== ===Amsterdam=== {{rquote|right|"Is Amsterdam, then. A Jewish town?"
"Nay; but ‘tis the Jerusalem of the West."|''Dreamers of the Ghetto'', [[Israel Zangwill]], 1898.[https://books.google.com/books?id=fN1e9FiGoxYC&pg=PA82&dq=%22jerusalem+of+the+west%22&hl=en&ei=mcWCTPy0OoGC8gbg-dyQAQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CFEQ6AEwCTgU#v=onepage&q=%22jerusalem%20of%20the%20west%22&f=false Dreamers of the Ghetto], Israel Zangwill, 1898. pg. 82.}} In Europe, [[Amsterdam]] was commonly associated with the term and was called ''Jeruzalem van het Westen'' in Dutch.Ridley Haim Herschell. [https://books.google.com/books?id=ghcFAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA27&dq=%22jerusalem+of+the+west%22&hl=en&ei=usWCTOuYKcP98AaKgfWIAw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CE8Q6AEwCTge#v=onepage&q=%22jerusalem%20of%20the%20west%22&f=false The Voice of Israel], 1845. pg. 27. [[Sephardic Jews]] from [[Spain]] and [[Portugal]] first settled there in the 17th-centuryAntonie Wessels. [https://books.google.com/books?id=De3ap-Bz5eIC&pg=PA9&dq=%22jerusalem+of+the+west%22&hl=en&ei=tL-CTPuoO8P78Abd7aWGBA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCwQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22jerusalem%20of%20the%20west%22&f=false Muslims in the West: can they be integrated], Peeters Publishers, 2006. pg. 9. {{ISBN|90-429-1684-2}}. and in 1672, there were an estimated 7,500 Jews living in the city.D. van Galen Last, Rolf Wolfswinkel. [https://books.google.com/books?id=sbKceAVo5KIC&pg=PA12&dq=%22jerusalem+of+the+west%22&hl=en&ei=88WCTPqzD8P68Abc39lS&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CFQQ6AEwCTgo#v=onepage&q=%22jerusalem%20of%20the%20west%22&f=false Anne Frank and after], Amsterdam University Press, 1996. pg. 17. {{ISBN|90-5356-177-3}}. Holland had a reputation of hospitality and tolerance which was rare in Europe at the time. It was "the first city in Europe where Jews were free from persecution and where they enjoyed religious liberty, ample economic opportunities and social equality."[https://books.google.com/books?id=sbIUAQAAIAAJ&q=%22Jerusalem+of+the+West%22&dq=%22Jerusalem+of+the+West%22&hl=en&ei=JtaCTNIXxPfwBsmw5OsB&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CC8Q6AEwAjiWAQ Beth Hatefutsoth: the first years], Beth Hatefutsoth, the Nahum Goldmann Museum of the Jewish Diaspora, 1983. pg. 53. The epithet signalled that the Jews felt comfortable in the city.D. van Galen Last, Rolf Wolfswinkel. [https://books.google.com/books?id=sbKceAVo5KIC&pg=PA12&dq=%22jerusalem+of+the+west%22&hl=en&ei=88WCTPqzD8P68Abc39lS&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CFQQ6AEwCTgo#v=onepage&q=%22jerusalem%20of%20the%20west%22&f=false Anne Frank and after], Amsterdam University Press, 1996. pg. 12. {{ISBN|90-5356-177-3}}. Prior to the [[Holocaust]], there were about 80,000 Jews living in Amsterdam.[http://spiegel.de/international/europe/a-926095.html Jewish identity in football clubs] ===Tlemcen=== In Northern Africa, [[Tlemcen]] in [[Algeria]] was called "Jerusalem of the West". In the 15th-century, the town was considered a major Jewish spiritual centre.John Hunwick. [https://books.google.com/books?id=olYnTwLL0QgC&pg=PA94&dq=%22jerusalem+of+the+west%22&hl=en&ei=mcWCTPy0OoGC8gbg-dyQAQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCcQ6AEwADgU#v=onepage&q=%22jerusalem%20of%20the%20west%22&f=false Jews of a Saharan oasis: elimination of the Tamantit community], Markus Wiener Publishers, 2006. Back Cover. {{ISBN|1-55876-346-5}}. [[André Chouraqui]] believed that there was a genuine geographical correspondence between the town and Jerusalem. He wrote: "We were living our dream in the midst of the beautiful countryside of the [[Maghreb]]. Tlemcen...resembles the city of David in altitude, climate, fauna and flora, to such an extent that we called in the Jerusalem of the Maghreb."Susan Slyomovics. [https://books.google.com/books?id=1H3qRTPJrRMC&pg=PA81&dq=%22jerusalem+of+the+west%22&hl=en&ei=tL-CTPuoO8P78Abd7aWGBA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0CEcQ6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=%22jerusalem%20of%20the%20west%22&f=false The walled Arab city in literature, architecture history: the living Medina in the Maghrib] "Geographies of Jewish Tlemcen." Routledge, 2001. pg. 81. {{ISBN|0-7146-5177-X}}. ===Other=== Other towns given the appellation include [[Toledo, Spain|Toledo]] Homero Aridjis, Ilan Stavans. [https://books.google.com/books?id=qGNfLCNeDbAC&pg=PA1&dq=Toledo+%22Jerusalem+of+the+West%22&hl=en&ei=19KCTPGIG8OB8gbWsPmnAg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CD4Q6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=Toledo%20%22Jerusalem%20of%20the%20West%22&f=false 1492: The Life and Times of Juan Cabezon of Castile], UNM Press, 2003. pg. 1. {{ISBN|0-8263-3096-7}}. and [[Antwerp]].Jonathan Irvine Israel, R. Salverda. [https://books.google.com/books?id=b94VNid92tMC&pg=PA289&dq=%22Jerusalem+of+the+West%22&hl=en&ei=CNSCTOeuLYH78AaQh8i4CA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CDEQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=%22Jerusalem%20of%20the%20West%22&f=false Dutch Jewry: its history and secular culture (1500-2000)], BRILL 2002. pg. 291. {{ISBN|90-04-12436-5}}. Many others towns in northern Africa were also called symbolically after Jerusalem: [[Ghardaia]], [[M'zab]] (Second Jerusalem), [[Djerba]], Tunisia (Ante-chamber of Jerusalem, Jerusalem of Africa), [[Ifrane]], Morocco (Little Jerusalem).Marie-Noëlle Bourguet, [[Lucette Valensi]], [[Nathan Wachtel]]. [https://books.google.com/books?id=xnKBfkagejQC&pg=PA81&dq=%22jerusalem+of+the+west%22&hl=en&ei=tL-CTPuoO8P78Abd7aWGBA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0CFEQ6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=%22jerusalem%20of%20the%20west%22&f=false Between memory and history, Volume 2], Taylor & Francis, 1990. pg. 81. {{ISBN|3-7186-5067-3}}. == See also == *[[Nowa Jerozolima (Warsaw)]], a small village established in 1774 for Jewish settlers in Mazovia, Poland. *[[Mokum]], Yiddish word meaning "safe haven", given to a number of towns in Holland and Germany. == References == {{reflist}} [[Category:City nicknames]] [[Category:Historic Jewish communities]]

'''Lellia Cracco Ruggini''' (born 20 September 1931) is an Italian historian of Late Antiquity and professor emerita of the [[University of Turin]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.accademiadellescienze.it/accademia/soci/lellia-cracco-ruggini|title=Lellia CRACCO RUGGINI|last=|first=|date=|website=Accademia delle scienze, Torino|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=28 March 2018}}</ref> Her particular interests are in economic and social history, the history of ideas, and modern and ancient historiography. She specialises in the period from the second to seventh centuries AD.
== Early life and education == She was born at [[Milan]] on 20 September 1931.<ref name=":0" /> In 1954 she graduated from the University of Pavia with a degree in literature and was awarded a PhD in 1963 by the University of Turin .<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.aibl.fr/membres/academiciens-depuis-1663/article/cracco-ruggini-lellia?lang=fr|title=CRACCO RUGGINI Lellia|last=|first=|date=2011-02-16|website=http://www.aibl.fr|language=fr|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-03-28}}</ref><ref name=":1" />
== Career == From 1957-1968 she taught Greek and Roman history at the [[University of Pavia]], becoming ''Libera Docente'' of Roman history and Latin epigraphy in 1963. She was Professor of Latin epigraphy at Pavia from 1965 to 1967.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":1" />
She was director of the Institute of Ancient History at Turin University from 1968 to 1975, where she taught Roman history, Greek history and Latin epigraphy within the faculty of literature and philosophy. In 1989 she was elected as a member of the Academy of Europe.<ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ae-info.org/ae/Member/Cracco_Ruggini_Lellia|title=Academy of Europe: Cracco Ruggini Lellia|last=|first=|date=|website=www.ae-info.org|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-03-28}}</ref> In 1995 she became professor emerita at Turin University.<ref name=":0" /> She was elected a foreign correspondent of the Académie des Inscriptions et Belles Lettres, France, in 2004.
She has held fellowships of the Italian Institute of Historical Study “Benedetto Croce” at Naples, the School for Advanced Studies at Paris, at the American Academy in Rome and twice made fellow of the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton New Jersey.<ref name=":0" />
She is co-director of the New History Magazine, of the Italian History Magazine, and from 1962 to 1967 she was secretary of Athenaeum review.<ref name=":2" />
She is a member of the Turin Academy of Science, the Lincean Academy, the National Society of Antiquaries of France (since 1991), the Institute of France, the European Academy at London, the Association for Late Antiquity at Paris and the Association for Late Antique Studies at Naples.<ref name=":0" />
== Prizes == *1962 "Alessandro Bonavera" prize awarded by Accademia delle Scienze of Turin <ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://www.ias.edu/scholars/lellia-cracco-ruggini|title=Lellia Cracco Ruggini|work=Institute for Advanced Study|access-date=2018-03-28|language=en}}</ref> *1966 "Stefano Iacini" prize for the best history book, awarded by the Cassa di Risparmio delle Province Lombarde, Milan.<ref name=":1" />
== Publications == She has published over 300 journal articles and books.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ae-info.org/ae/Member/Cracco_Ruggini_Lellia/Publications|title=Academy of Europe: Publications|last=|first=|date=|website=www.ae-info.org|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-03-28}}</ref> Some of the most notable are:<ref name=":2" />
1961, 2001. ''Economia e società nell’ Italia Annonaria. Rapporti fra agricoltura e commercio dal IV al VI secolo d. C''.
1966. « Un riflesso del mito di Alessandro nell’Historia Augusta » (in ''Beiträge zur Historia Augusta Forschung'', 3).
1972. « Simboli di battaglia ideologica nel tardo Ellenismo (Roma, Atene, Costantinopoli ; Numa, Empedocle, Cristo) » (in ''Studi Storici in onore di Ottorino Bertolini'', I).
1974. « Leggenda e realtà degli Etiopi nella cultura tardoimperiale » (in ''Atti del IV Congresso Int. di St. Etiopici'').
1987. « Storia totale di una piccola città : Vicenza romana » (in ''Storia di Vicenza'', I).
1989. « Arnaldo Momigliano e il Tardoantico » (in ''Omaggio ad Arnaldo Momigliano : Storia e storiografia sul mondo antico'').
1989. « La città imperiale » (in ''Storia di Roma'', IV).
1992. « Acque e lagune da periferia del mondo a fulcro di una nuova civilitas » (in ''Storia di Venezia'', I).
1993. « Il Tardoantico : per una tipologia dei punti critici » (in ''Storia di Roma'', Einaudi, III, 1).
1996, 1997, 2000. « Introduzione : La Storia Antica oggi » (in ''Storia Antica : come leggere le fonti'').
2003. « Iatrosofistica pagana, “filosofia” cristiana e medicina (IV-VI secolo) » (in ''Consuetudinis amor. Fragments d’histoire culturelle (IIe-VIe siècle) : Mélanges en l’honneur de Jean-Pierre Callu'').
2006. « La sessualità nell’etica pagano-cristiana tardoantica » (in ''LIII Settimana del CISAM'', I)
2008. « Roma e i Barbari in età tardoantica » (in ''Roma e i Barbari. La nascita di un nuovo mondo'', catalogue de l’exposition).
2008. « Gli studi storici sul Tardoantico in Italia nell’età di Riegl » (in ''Alois Riegl (1858-1905) un secolo dopo'').
2008. « Terre e acque : città e campagne fra antichità e medioevo » (in LV Settimana del CISAM, I).
2008. « Le amicizie “europee” di Gregorio Magno e la sua “politica delle reliquie” » (in ''Gregorio Magno e la Sardegna''. Convegno Int.).
2009. « Alimentare i cittadini, i rustici e i milites fra Tardoantico e Alto Medioevo » (in ''LVI Settimana di studio del CISAM'', I).
2009. « Il Codice Teodosiano e le eresie » (in Droit, religion et société dans le Code Théodosien).
2010. « Tra fine IV e inizî V secolo in due dittici : qualche problema » (in ''Il secolo dei dittici'', Seminario Int.).
2011. « Pontifices : un caso di osmosi linguistica » (in ''Pagans and Christians in the Roman Empire : The Breaking of a Dialogue (IVth-VIth Century A.D.''). Proceedings of the International Conference at the Monastery of Bose).
2011. ''Gli Ebrei in età tardoantica. Presenze, intolleranze, incontri''.

This page lists chronologically '''the first achievements in cinema'''. The development of cinema is characterised by technological breakthroughs, from early experiments in the recording of day-to-day activity, experiments in colour, different formats and sound. From the 1970s, the development of [[computer-generated imagery]] has become integral to the way that films are produced. In parallel with the developments in technology, its content and the way it reflects society and its concerns and the way society responds to it have changed too. The list attempts to address some of these events. {|id="toc" class="toc" summary="Contents" ! {{MediaWiki:Toc}} |- | | '''[[#19th century|19th century]]:''' [[#1860s|1860s]] • [[#1870s|1870s]] • [[#1880s|1880s]] • [[#1890s|1890s]]
'''[[#20th century|20th century]]:''' [[#1900s|1900s]] • [[#1910s|1910s]] • [[#1920s|1920s]] • [[#1930s|1930s]] • [[#1940s|1940s]] • [[#1950s|1950s]] • [[#1960s|1960s]] • [[#1970s|1970s]] • [[#1980|1980s]] • [[#1990s|1990s]]

__NOTOC__ |} ==19th century== ===1860s=== ====1867-68==== * [[Chronophotography]] is the first time that movement is captured in several frames of print. ===1870s=== ==== 1874 ==== * French astronomer [[Pierre Janssen|P.J.C. Janssen]] came up with the idea for a "revolver photographic". This huge camera system used a Maltese cross-type mechanism, very similar to the system that would later be of great importance in the development of movie cameras. He successfully captured both [[Transit of Venus|transits of Venus]], 1874 in Japan, that of 1882 at [[Oran]] in Algeria. The motion picture was known as [[Passage de Venus]]{{Citation|title=The Passage of Venus|url=http://www.imdb.com/title/tt3155794/|access-date=2018-08-19}} ====1878==== *Using a fast-motion series of 24 cameras [[Eadweard Muybridge]] films a horse in motion, ''[[Sallie Gardner at a Gallop]]''.{{cite book | last=Clegg | first=Brian | title=The Man Who Stopped Time| publisher=Joseph Henry Press | year=2007 | isbn=978-0-309-10112-7}}{{cite web | title=Cantor exhibit showcases motion-study photography | url= http://news.stanford.edu/news/2003/february12/muybridge-212.html| work=Stanford University| accessdate=2010-02-03}} ===1880s=== ====1880==== *[[Eadweard Muybridge]] projects the moving images of ''[[Sallie Gardner at a Gallop]]'' on a screen when he gave a presentation{{cite web | title= Eadward Muybridge (1830-1904) | url= http://www.iphf.org/Hall_Of_Fame/Inducties_Bios/Eadweard_Muybridge_Bio.html| work=International Photography Hall of Fame | accessdate=2010-02-03}} at the California School of Fine Arts, making this exhibit the earliest known motion picture exhibition. ====1882==== *[[Étienne-Jules Marey]] develops the Chronophotographe, which can take 12 pictures per second. ====1888==== *In [[Leeds]], [[England]] [[Louis Le Prince]] films ''[[Roundhay Garden Scene]]'', believed to be the first motion picture recorded.{{cite book|title=Life in the United Kingdom: The Land and the People|first=David|last=William|publisher=New Africa Press|isbn=978-9987-16-017-4|page=173}} ===1890s=== ====1889 or 1890==== *''[[Monkeyshines]]'', by [[William Kennedy Dickson]] and [[William Heise]]. Believed to be the first film shot in the [[United States]].{{cite web|url=http://www.rowthree.com/2010/11/15/133-years-of-film-18891990-monkey-shines-no-1/|title=133 Years of Film:1889/1990 - Monkey Shines No. 1|publisher=Rowhtree.com|accessdate=2012-02-16}} An experimental film made to test the original cylinder [[Kinetograph]] format. ====1891==== *''[[Dickson Greeting]]'' aka ''[[Monkeyshines]] 2'', by William Kennedy Dickson is the first public demonstration of motion pictures in the United States. The [[National Federation of Women’s Clubs]] are shown a 3 second clip of Dickson passing a hat in front of himself, and reaching for it with his other hand on May 20, 1891 at Edison's laboratory. ====1892==== *On 28 October 1892 [[Charles-Émile Reynaud]] gave the first public performance of a moving picture show at the [[Musée Grévin]] in [[Paris]], the [[Théâtre Optique]]. The show, billed as ''Pantomimes Lumineuses'', included three cartoons, ''[[Pauvre Pierrot]]'', ''[[Un bon bock]]'', and ''[[Le Clown et ses chiens]]'', each consisting of 500 to 600 individually painted images and lasting about 15 minutes. The film was the first to use [[film perforations|perforations]]. ====1893==== *''[[Blacksmith Scene]]'', by [[William Kennedy Dickson]]. The first Kinetoscope film shown in public exhibition on May 9, 1893 and is the earliest known example of actors performing a role in a film.{{cite web |url=http://www.silentera.com/PSFL/data/B/BlacksmithScene1893.html | title=PFSL : Blacksmith Scene | work=Silent Era |accessdate=2012-02-16 }} *The world's first film production studio, [[Edison's Black Maria|the Black Maria]], or the Kinetographic Theater, was completed on the grounds of Edison's laboratories at West Orange, New Jersey, for the purpose of making film strips for the [[Kinetoscope]]. Construction began in December 1892Robinson (1997). p. 23. ====1894==== * On April 14, 1894, a public Kinetoscope parlor was opened by the Holland Bros. in New York City at 1155 Broadway, on the corner of 27th Street—the first commercial motion picture house. The venue had ten machines, set up in parallel rows of five, each showing a different movie. For 25 cents a viewer could see all the films in either row; half a dollar gave access to the entire bill.The machines were modified so that they did not operate by nickel slot. According to Hendricks (1966), in each row "attendants switched the instruments on and off for customers who had paid their twenty-five cents" (p. 13). For more on the Hollands, see Peter Morris, ''Embattled Shadows: A History of Canadian Cinema, 1895–1939'' (Montreal and Kingston, Canada; London; and Buffalo, New York: McGill-Queen's University Press, 1978), pp. 6–7. Morris states that Edison wholesaled the Kinetoscope at $200 per machine; in fact, as described below, $250 seems to have been the most common figure at first. *''Dorlita in the Passion Dance'' Banned in New Jersey after use in peepshows. Russell Kick quotes the work ''Censorship'' as saying it "was probably the first [film] to be banned in the United States."{{cite book |last=Kick |first=Russ |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=The Disinformation Book Of Lists |publisher=The Disinformation Company |year=2004 |location= |pages=List 68: "16 Movies Banned in the U.S.", Pages 236–238 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=utssHzXYsWoC&printsec=frontcover&dq=isbn=0-9729529-4-2&cd=1#v=onepage&q= |doi= |id= |isbn=0-9729529-4-2 |nopp=true}} *''la Sortie des Usines'', the first film to be made in France. *[[The Dickson Experimental Sound Film]] by William Kennedy Dickson. It is the first known film with live-recorded sound and appears to be the first motion picture made for the [[Kinetophone]], the proto-[[sound film|sound-film]] system developed by Dickson and [[Thomas Edison]].{{cite web|url=http://www.filmthreat.com/features/2082/|title=THE BOOTLEG FILES: "DICKSON EXPERIMENTAL SOUND FILM"|publisher=Filmthreat.com|accessdate=2012-02-18}} ====1895==== *First hand-colored film, ''[[Annabelle Serpentine Dance]]'' by [[William Kennedy Dickson]].{{cite book|title=Chromatic Cinema: A History of Screen Colour|author=Richard Misek|page=15|isbn=978-1-4443-3239-1}} *[[Charles Francis Jenkins]] displays the [[Phantascope]], the first patented [[Movie projector|Film projector]]. *''[[Incident at Clovelly Cottage]]'' by [[Robert W. Paul]] and [[Birt Acres]] is the first film to be made in the United Kingdom.{{cite web|url=http://www.britishcinemagreats.com/cinema_history/pre_british/page_1.htm|title=The guide to British Cinema and Movie History background|publisher=britishcinemagreats.com|accessdate=2012-02-17}} *''[[History of the Kinetograph, Kinetoscope, and Kinetophonograph]]'' by Antonia and [[William Kennedy Dickson]], considered the first book of history on film, is published.{{Cite book|last=Bawden|first=Liz-Anne|year=1976|title=The Oxford Companion to Film|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|isbn=9780192115416|ref={{SfnRef|Bawden|1976}}}} ====1896==== *The first building dedicated exclusively to showing motion pictures was the Vitascope Hall, established on Canal Street, New Orleans, Louisiana June 26 — it was converted from a vacant store.{{cite web|url=http://www.bestofneworleans.com/gambit/where-was-the-first-permanent-movie-theater-in-the-united-states-located/Content?oid=1278809 |title=Where was the first permanent movie theatre in the United States located? |publisher=bestofneworleans.com |accessdate=2012-02-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120525053347/http://www.bestofneworleans.com/gambit/where-was-the-first-permanent-movie-theater-in-the-united-states-located/Content?oid=1278809 |archivedate=2012-05-25 |df= }} *Later that year on October 19, the [[Edisonia Hall]] opened in [[Buffalo, New York]] in the [[Ellicott Square Building]]. The Edisonia was the first known dedicated, purpose-built motion picture theater in the world.{{cite web|url=http://www.buffalofilmfestival.com/edisoniahallbuffalo.html|title=Help us find the Edison|publisher=Buffalo Film Festival|accessdate=2011-05-20}} *[[Alice Guy-Blaché]], the first female [[film director]]{{cite web|url=http://www.herstorynetwork.com/women-making-herstory/breaking-glass-ceiling/alice-guy-blache/|title=Alice Guy Blache|publisher=The Herstory Network|accessdate=2012-02-17}} makes ''[[La Fée aux Choux]]'' ''(The Cabbage Fairy)'' acknowledged as the first [[narrative]] fiction film. *In ''[[The Kiss (1896 film)|The Kiss]]'', May Irwin and John Rice re-enact the kiss from the New York stage hit ''[[The Widow Jones]]'', the first film of a couple kissing.{{cite web|url=http://www.pictureshowman.com/movies_featuredmovie2.cfm|title=The May Irwin Kiss|publisher=pictureshowman.com|accessdate=2012-02-18}} ====1899==== *The first example of object manipulation and [[stop-motion animation]] was the short film by Albert E. Smith and [[J. Stuart Blackton]] called ''The Humpty Dumpty Circus''.https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0000704/ *''[[King John (1899 film)|King John]]'' is the first film adaptation of the work of [[William Shakespeare]]. The film features [[Herbert Beerbohm Tree]] in the title role and features the death scene from ''[[King John (play)|King John]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.screenonline.org.uk/film/id/439193/index.html|title=King John|publisher=BFI|accessdate=2011-05-20}} ==20th century== ===1900s=== ====1901==== *''[[Histoire d'un crime (film)|Histoire d'un crime]]'', directed by [[Ferdinand Zecca]] was the first film to use [[flashback (narrative)|flashbacks]] to create a non-linear narrative.{{cite web|url=http://www.filmsite.org/1901-filmhistory.html|title=The Year 1901|publisher=Filmsite.org|accessdate=28 December 2017}} *The earliest known use of [[intertitles]] was in the British film ''[[Scrooge, or, Marley's Ghost]]''.{{cite book|title=Dickens on Screen|first=Kamilla|last=Elliot|page=117|isbn=978-0521001243|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mpdrgN082GoC&pg=PA117&lpg=PA117&dq=1901+intertitles&source=bl&ots=nraWDTMOAp&sig=bChGp_xDj1VPbJrK5I5PSKi6yIo&hl=en&sa=X&ei=kaeBUPOXBerO0QXMgoDQBA&ved=0CDYQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=1901%20intertitles&f=false}} ====1902==== *''[[Edward Raymond Turner]]'s children'' and several other very short test films, the earliest known moving pictures photographed in color.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-19423951|title=World's first colour moving pictures discovered|accessdate=2012-09-12}} *''[[A Trip to the Moon]]'' is the first [[science fiction film|sci-fi movie]]. ====1904==== *''[[The Great Train Robbery (1904 film)|The Great Train Robbery]]'', directed by [[Siegmund Lubin]] was the first film [[remake]].{{cite web | url =http://all-that-is-interesting.com/first-movie-sequel | title = These Are The Very First Movie Sequel, Remake, And Reboots Ever | last = Jones | first = Briana | date = 2 March 2016 | website = all-that-is-interesting.com | access-date = 13 November 2017 | quote = In 1904, director Siegmund Lubin released his own version of the film, under the very same name, and made it nearly identical to its predecessor.}} ====1906==== *''[[Humorous Phases of Funny Faces]]'' directed by [[J. Stuart Blackton]] is the first 2D animated film.{{cite book|last=Beckerman|first=Howard|title=Animation: the whole story|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=EjW6cCE4v1QC&pg=PA16|accessdate=16 August 2011|date=2003-09-01|publisher=Skyhorse Publishing Inc.|isbn=978-1-58115-301-9|page=16}} *''[[The Story of the Kelly Gang]]'' by [[Charles Tait (film director)|Charles Tait]] is the first feature film to be released.{{cite journal | url = http://portal.unesco.org/en/ev.php-URL_ID=37899&URL_DO=DO_TOPIC&URL_SECTION=201.html| title = Return of the Kelly Gang| journal = The [[UNESCO Courier]]| issn = 1993-8616| issue = 2007 #5| last = Chichester| first = Jo | publisher = [[UNESCO]]}} ====1907==== *January 19, [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] publishes reviews of two films, ''[[An Exciting Honeymoon]]'' and ''[[The Life of a Cowboy]]'' by [[Edwin S. Porter]]. These are believed to be the first film reviews published.{{cite web|url=http://www.things-and-other-stuff.com/6328/today-in-1907-variety-first-movie-reviews/|title=Today in 1907 - Variety publishes first movie reviews|publisher=things-and-other-stuff.com|accessdate=2012-02-17}} *''[[L'Enfant prodigue (film)|L'Enfant prodigue]]'' is the first feature film produced in Europe.{{citation needed|date= September 2017}} ====1908==== *''[[A Visit to the Seaside]]'' is the first film to use [[Kinemacolor]].{{cite web|url=http://www.allmovie.com/work/a-visit-to-the-seaside-151414|title=A Visit to the seaside|publisher=Allmovie.com|accessdate=2012-02-16}} *''[[The Assassination of the Duke of Guise]]'' is the first film to have a [[Film score|score]] specifically written for it, by French composer [[Camille Saint-Saëns]].[[Richard Davis (composer)|Davis, Richard]] (1999). ''Complete Guide to Film Scoring'', Berklee Press, Boston. {{ISBN|0-634-00636-3}}, p. 17 ====1909==== *The first full length feature film produced in the United States was an adaptation of [[Victor Hugo]]'s novel ''[[Les Miserables (1909 film)|Les Misérables]]''.{{citation needed|date= August 2017}} ===1910s=== ====1910==== * The German film serial, ''[[Arsène Lupin contra Sherlock Holmes]]'' directed by [[Viggo Larsen]] was the first film [[crossover (fiction)|crossover]].{{citation needed|date= August 2017}} * For the first time,{{citation needed|date= September 2017}} the rights to adapt a novel are bought from a publisher, (Little, Brown & Company who published [[Helen Hunt Jackson]]'s novel ''[[Ramona (novel)|Ramona]]''. The [[Ramona (1910 film)|film]] is made by [[D.W. Griffith]]. * D.W. Griffith makes ''[[In Old California (1910 film)|In Old California]]'', the first film to be made in [[Hollywood]].{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodzing.com/about-hollywood/history/|title=History of Hollywood|publisher=Hollywoodzing.com|accessdate=2011-05-28}} ====1912==== *''[[With Our King and Queen Through India]]'', a documentary recording Indian celebrations around the coronation of [[George V]], is the first feature film to be released in colour, using the Kinemacolour system.{{citation needed|date= August 2017}} ====1915==== *''[[The Birth of a Nation]]'', directed by [[D.W. Griffith]] was the first big budget Hollywood epic.{{citation needed|date= August 2017}} ====1916==== *''[[The Fall of a Nation]]'', directed by [[Thomas Dixon Jr.]] was the first film [[sequel]].{{cite book |title=The Story of Hollywood: An Illustrated History|first=Gregory Paul |last=Williams |year= |publisher= |page=87 |isbn= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9W4R_CZtFe8C&pg=PA87&dq=the+fall+of+a+nation+first+sequel&lr=#v=onepage&q=the%20fall%20of%20a%20nation%20first%20sequel&f=false}} ====1917==== *The first [[List of animated feature films|animated feature film]] was ''[[El Apóstol]]'' by [[Quirino Cristiani]] from [[Argentina]].{{cite web|url=http://www.awn.com/mag/issue1.4/articles/bendazzi1.4.html|title=The Untold Story of Argentina's Pioneer Animator|publisher=awn.com|accessdate=2012-02-17}} *''[[The Gulf Between (1917 film)|The Gulf Between]]'' directed by [[Wray Physioc]] is the first feature film to use [[Technicolor]].{{cite web|url=http://www.buffalofilmfestival.com/buffalomovietreasures/gulfbetween1918.html|title=The Gulf Between - 1918 - Technicolor Premiere, Buffalo NY|publisher=Buffalo Film Festival|accessdate=2012-02-17|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120126082927/http://www.buffalofilmfestival.com/buffalomovietreasures/gulfbetween1918.html|archivedate=2012-01-26|df=}} ===1920s=== ====1921==== *''[[A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court (1921 film)|A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court]]'' (1921), directed by [[Emmett J. Flynn]] was the first film to feature [[list of time travel works of fiction|time travel]] to the past.''The American Film Catalog Feature Films: 1921-30'' by The American Film I ====1922==== *The first colour feature film made in Hollywood, ''[[The Toll of the Sea]]'', starring [[Anna May Wong]]. *First feature film in 3D. ''[[The Power of Love (1922 film)|The Power of Love]]'' by [[Nat Deverich]],{{cite web|url=http://www.3dgear.com/scsc/movies/firsts.html|title=3D Movie Firsts|publisher=3DGear.com|date=18 May 2011}} which premiered at the [[Ambassador Hotel (Los Angeles)|Ambassador Hotel Theater]] in [[Los Angeles]] on September 27.{{cite web|url=http://www.silentera.com/PSFL/data/P/PowerofLove1922.html |title=silentera.com |publisher=silentera.com |date= |accessdate=2010-10-14}} ====1923==== *[[16 mm film]] is introduced by [[Eastman Kodak]] in the United States. ====1927==== *''[[The Jazz Singer]]'' starring [[Al Jolson]] is the first feature film with recorded dialogue, using the [[Vitaphone]] system.{{cite web|url=http://www.spannerworks.net/reference/10_3a.asp|title=Movie Sound Chronology|publisher=Spannerworks.net|date=18 May 2011}} ''The Jazz Singer'' is also the first [[musical film]]. *''[[Napoléon (1927 film)|Napoleon]]'' by [[Abel Gance]] is the first film to be filmed in the [[Widescreen|widescreen format]].{{cite web|url=http://www.lesliehalliwell.com/four_star/significance/napoleon_s.html|title=Napoleon - Significance|publisher=Lesliehalliwell.com|accessdate=2012-02-18}} ====1928==== *''[[Lights of New York (1928 film)|Lights of New York]]'', directed by [[Bryan Foy]] is the first all talking feature film.{{cite web|url=http://www.georgegroves.org.uk/vitaphone.html|title=Vitaphone (1928-31)|publisher=georgegroves.org|accessdate=2012-02-17}} *''[[Wings (1927 film)|Wings]]'', directed by [[William A. Wellman]] is the first film to win the [[Academy Award for Best Picture]]. *''[[The Viking (1928 film)|The Viking]]'' is the first feature-length film in color with sound (music and sound effects only).{{citation needed|date= September 2017}} ====1929==== *The First [[Academy Awards|Academy Award]] ceremony takes place at the Hollywood Roosevelt Hotel, Los Angeles on May 1. ''[[Sunrise: A Song of Two Humans]]'' wins the award for "Unique and Artistic Production" (denoting artistic strength) and ''[[Wings (1927 film)|Wings]]'' wins the award for "Outstanding Picture, Production" (denoting technical production quality). Both awards were eliminated and merged the next year into the single [[Academy Award for Best Picture|Best Picture]] category. [[Emil Jannings]] and [[Janet Gaynor]] won the awards for best actor and actress, which were awarded for work in a number of different films throughout the year. Acting categories were later narrowed to honor work on a single film.{{cite web|url=http://www.oscars.org/awards/academyawards/about/history.html|title=History of the Academy Awards|publisher=Oscars.org|accessdate=2012-02-17}} *''[[Blackmail (1929 film)|Blackmail]]'', directed by [[Alfred Hitchcock]] was the first British sound film.{{citation needed|date= September 2017}} ===1930s=== ====1930==== *''[[Fiddlesticks (film)|Fiddlesticks]]'', directed by [[Ub Iwerks]] was the first complete sound cartoon to be shot in two-strip [[Technicolor]].{{cite book|last1=Robertson|first1=Patrick|title=Robertson's Book of Firsts|date=2011|publisher=Bloomsbury|location=London|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2TEEaCrPiWsC&dq=|accessdate=24 May 2017}} *''[[The Big Trail]]'', directed by [[Raoul Walsh]] was the first film to use a swear word, given by John Wayne as Breck Coleman.{{citation needed|date= August 2017}} ====1931==== *''[[Peludópolis]]'', directed by Qirino Christiani is the first animated feature with sound. ====1932==== *The first animated film to use the full, three-color [[Technicolor]] method was ''[[Flowers and Trees]]'' made by Disney Studios. The film was also the first to win the [[Academy Award for Best Animated Short Film]].{{cite web|url=http://www.filmschoolrejects.com/features/short-film-of-the-day-disney-flowers-and-trees-the-first-best-animated-short-oscar-winner.php|title=Short Film of the Day:Disney's 'Flowers and Trees'|publisher=Filmschoolrejects.com|accessdate=2012-02-17}} *''[[Love Me Tonight]]'' by [[Rouben Mamoulian]] is credited as the first film to use a [[zoom lens]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nbrmp.org/features/col.baac.2004.jan.cfm|title=Between action and cut|publisher=National Board of Review of Motion Pictures|accessdate=2012-02-17}} *The [[Venice Film Festival]] runs from 6–21 August, the first [[film festival]].{{cite web|url=http://www.labiennale.org/en/biennale/history/|title=La Biennale di Venezia - History of the Venice Biennale|publisher=labiennale.org|accessdate=2012-02-17}} *''[[White Zombie (film)|White Zombie]]'' by [[Victor Hugo Halperin|Victor Halperin]] was the first [[zombie film]]. ====1933==== * ''[[The Crooked Circle (1932 film)|The Crooked Circle]]'' was the first film to be broadcast on television, on March 10 in [[Los Angeles]].{{citation needed|date= August 2017}} ====1935==== *''[[Becky Sharp (film)|Becky Sharp]]'', starring [[Miriam Hopkins]], was the first feature-length film in three-strip [[Technicolor]].{{citation needed|date= September 2017}} ====1937==== *[[Disney]]'s ''[[Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs (1937 film)|Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs]]'' was the first full length [[Traditional animation|cel animated]] feature film.Smith, Dave. ''[[Disney A to Z]]'', Third Edition, (2006), page 33. ====1939==== * ''[[Raffles (1939 film)|Raffles]]'' was the first film to show a [[television]] set. ===1940s=== ====1940==== *First African American to win the [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress]]: [[Hattie McDaniel]] (''[[Gone with the Wind (film)|Gone with the Wind]]'', 1939). *[[Walt Disney]]'s ''[[Fantasia (1940 film)|Fantasia]]'' is the first film with [[surround sound]], using Disney's [[Fantasound]] system. ====1943==== *First twins to win the [[Academy Award for Best Adapted Screenplay]]: [[Julius J. Epstein|Julius]] [[Philip G. Epstein|and Philip Epstein]], (''[[Casablanca (film)|Casablanca]]'', 1942). ====1946==== *The first [[Cannes Film Festival]] takes place from September 20 to October 5.{{cite web|url=http://www.history.com/this-day-in-history/first-cannes-film-festival|title=First Cannes Film Festival|publisher=History.com|accessdate=2012-02-17}} ====1947==== *First feature film in 3D and partly in color: ''[[Robinzon Kruzo|Robinson Crusoe]]'' by [[Alexander Andreyevsky]]. ====1948==== *First African-American man to receive an Academy Award: [[James Baskett]] ([[Honorary Academy Award]] for his portrayal of "[[Uncle Remus]]" in ''[[Song of the South]]'', 1946) (See also: [[Sidney Poitier]], [[#1960s|1964)]] *The first [[British Academy Film Awards]] ceremony takes place with ''[[The Best Years of Our Lives]]'', winning the [[BAFTA Award for Best Film|award for best film]].{{cite web|url=http://www.radiotimes.com/news/2012-02-12/the-bafta-film-awards-in-numbers|title=The Bafta Film Awards in numbers|publisher=The Radio Times|accessdate=2012-02-17}} ===1950s=== ====1951==== *''[[Distant Drums]]'' is the first film to use the [[Wilhelm scream]]. ====1953==== *''[[The Robe (film)|The Robe]]'' is the first film to be released in [[CinemaScope]].{{citation needed|date= August 2017}} ===1960s=== ====1964==== *First movie with African-American interracial marriage: ''[[One Potato, Two Potato (film)|One Potato, Two Potato]]'',[http://www.greencine.com/static/primers/black-1.jsp GreenCine.com: "Black Cinema", by David Hudson (no date)] {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/5zzGrcfON?url=http://www.greencine.com/static/primers/black-1.jsp |date=2011-07-07 }} Note: Asian-American interracial marriage had previously been portrayed. actors [[Bernie Hamilton]] and [[Barbara Barrie]], written by Orville H. Hampton, Raphael Hayes, directed by [[Larry Peerce]] *First African-American man to win the [[Academy Award for Best Actor]]: [[Sidney Poitier]] (''[[Lilies of the Field (1963 film)|Lilies of the Field]]'', 1963) (See also: [[James Baskett]], [[#1940s|1948)]] ===1970s=== ====1970==== *''[[Tiger Child]]'', the first film in the [[IMAX]] format is made. Directed by [[Donald Brittain]] and produced by [[Roman Kroitor]] and [[Kichi Ichikawa]], it premiered at [[Expo '70]] in [[Osaka, Japan]] at the [[Fuyo Group|Fuji Group]] Pavilion.{{cite web |url=http://www.ieee.ca/millennium/imax/imax_chronology.html |title=IMAX'S Chronology of Techonological ''(sic)'' Events |accessdate=2008-02-22 |work=IEEE Canada, Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers}} ====1971==== *The first permanent IMAX theatre, [[Cinesphere]] is built on the grounds of [[Ontario Place]] in [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], [[Canada]].{{cite web|url=http://www.imax.com/corporate/history/|title=History|publisher=Imax.com|accessdate=2012-02-17}} ====1973==== *First use of 2D computer animation in a significant entertainment feature film, ''[[Westworld (film)|Westworld]]''. The point of view of [[Yul Brynner]]'s gunslinger was achieved with [[raster graphics]].{{cite news| url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/movies/news/2004-09-14-sky-captain-cgi_x.htm | work=USA Today | title='Sky Captain' takes CGI to limit | first1=Scott | last1=Bowles | date=2004-09-15 | accessdate=2010-05-25}}[http://www.filmsite.org/visualeffects9.html Visual and Special Effects Film Milestones - Part 9] ====1975==== *''[[Jaws (film)|Jaws]]'' was the first summer blockbuster film.{{citation needed|date= August 2017}} *''[[Barry Lyndon (film)|Barry Lyndon]]'' was the first film with scenes shot entirely by natural candlelight.{{citation needed|date= July 2018}} ====1976==== *''[[The Young Teacher]]'' is the first film to be commercially released on [[VHS]].{{cite web|url=https://www.primermagazine.com/2009/field-manual/know-it-all-the-first-movie-commercially-released-on-vhs|title=Know It All: The First Movie Commercially Released on VHS|publisher=Primer magazine|accessdate=29 December 2017}} *[[Steadicam]] is used for the first time in a production: [[Hal Ashby]]'s ''[[Bound for Glory (film)|Bound for Glory]]'',{{cite web|url=http://www.steadi-onfilms.com.au/steadicam_history.html|title=Steadicam history|publisher=Steadi-onnfilms.com.au|accessdate=2012-02-17}} however [[John Schlesinger]]'s ''[[Marathon Man (film)|Marathon Man]]'', released the same year is the first to be commercially released. ====1977==== *''[[Star Wars (film)|Star Wars: Episode IV – A New Hope]]'' pioneered visual effects, thanks to [[Industrial Light & Magic]], which in turn led the studio to be founded. as well as making merchandising aspect central to profit-making. ====1978==== *''[[Superman (1978 film)|Superman: The Movie]]'' is the first film with a computer-generated title sequence.{{citation needed|date= August 2017}} ===1980=== ====1981==== *''[[Looker]]'' by is the first film to feature a [[Computer-generated imagery|CGI]] human character, Cindy. Also, first use of 3D shaded CGI.[http://www.filmsite.org/visualeffects10.html Visual and Special Effects Film Milestones - Part 10]Netzley, pg. 49. ====1982==== *For ''[[Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan]]'', [[Industrial Light & Magic|ILM]] computer graphics division develops "Genesis Effect", the first use of fractal-generated landscape in a film.{{cite news|author=Pegoraro, Rob|date=June 29, 2008|title=Incredibles, Inc; The story of how computer programmers transformed the art of movie animation|work=[[The Washington Post]]|page=W8}} Bill Reeves leads the Genesis Effect programming team, and creates a new graphics technique called Particle Systems. ====1983==== *''[[Rock & Rule]]'' is the first animated film to use computer graphics.[http://www.filmsite.org/visualeffects11.html Visual and Special Effects Film Milestones - Part 11] ====1984==== *''[[The Last Starfighter]]'' uses CGI for all spaceship shots, replacing traditional models. First use of 'integrated CGI' where the effects are supposed to represent real world objects. *''[[The Sensorium]]'' is regarded the world's first [[4D film]].http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/movies/cinema-with-a-new-dimension-20111006-1la3c.html#ixzz3Ci7Na2Cx ====1985==== *In ''[[Young Sherlock Holmes]]'', [[Lucasfilm]] creates the first [[Rendering (computer graphics)|photorealistic]] CGI character, 'stained glass knight' with 10 seconds of screentime.Netzley, 246.[http://www.filmsite.org/visualeffects11.html Visual and Special Effects Film Milestones - Part 12] ====1986==== *At the Canada Pavilion in [[Expo 86]], Vancouver, [[Canada]] the first showing of 3D Imax takes place. ====1988==== *''[[Tin Toy]]'' by [[John Lasseter]] becomes the first computer-animated short film to win an Academy Award.{{cite web|url=http://www.openculture.com/2011/12/the_short_films_that_saved_pixar.html|title=The Short Films That Saved Pixar|publisher=openculture.com|accessdate=2012-02-17}} ===1990s=== ====1990==== *''[[The Rescuers Down Under]]'' is both [[The Walt Disney Company|Disney]]'s first theatrical sequel and the first 2D animated film to be animated significantly on computers.{{citation needed|date= August 2017}} ====1991==== *[[Beauty and the Beast (1991 film)|Beauty and the Beast]] is the first animated film to have an Academy Award nomination for Best Picture. ====1995==== *''[[Toy Story]]'' by [[John Lasseter]] is the first feature film to be made entirely using CGI.{{cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/e/a/1996/02/01/STYLE8516.dtl|title=Three Pixar execs get special Oscars|date=February 1, 1996|publisher=''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]''|accessdate=March 12, 2009}} *''[[Casper (film)|Casper]]'', the first CGI lead character in feature-length film (preceded ''Toy Story'' by six months). ====1998==== *''[[Titanic (1997 film)|Titanic]]'' by [[James Cameron]] becomes the first film to cost $200 million and to earn more than $1 billion worldwide.{{cite news | title = ''Titanic'' sinks competitors without a trace | publisher = BBC | date = February 25, 1998 | url =http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/59913.stm | accessdate=February 19, 2007}} ==21st century== ===2000s=== ====2000==== * First [[digital cinema]] projection in Europe by Philippe Binant with DLP CINEMA technology for the release of ''[[Toy Story 2]]''.''[[Cahiers du cinéma]]'', n°hors-série, Paris, April 2000, p. 32. Cf. also [http://www.academiecine.tv/acces_public/Histoire.pdf ''Histoire des communications'', 2011, p. 10.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121029054701/http://www.academiecine.tv/acces_public/Histoire.pdf |date=2012-10-29 }} *''[[O Brother, Where Art Thou?]]'' by the [[Coen brothers]] is the first feature film to be entirely color corrected by digital means.{{cite web|last=Robertson|first=Barbara|title=CGSociety — The Colorists|work=The Colorists|publisher=The CGSociety| date=2006-05-01|url=http://features.cgsociety.org/story_custom.php?story_id=3549|accessdate=2007-10-24| page=3}} ====2001==== *''[[Final Fantasy: The Spirits Within]]'' is the first feature film to use [[motion capture]] to create characters. *''[[Spirited Away]]'' was the first anime film to win an academy award (best animated feature).{{citation needed|date= August 2017}} ====2002==== *''[[Russian Ark]]'' by [[Alexander Sokurov]] is the first feature film to be shot entirely in uncompressed [[high definition video]].{{cite web|url=http://www.artificial-eye.com/film.php?dvd=ART256DVD&plugs&qt=true&wm=false|title=Russian Ark|publisher=Artificial Eye|accessdate=2012-02-17}} It is also the first feature film to consist of a single unedited take. ====2004==== *''[[Able Edwards]]'', the first movie with all-CGI backgrounds and live actors.{{cite web |url=http://www.roguecinema.com/article1018.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-02-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120311135646/http://www.roguecinema.com/article1018.html |archivedate=2012-03-11 |df= }} *''[[The Polar Express (film)|The Polar Express]]'' by [[Robert Zemeckis]], the first CGI movie that used motion capture for all actors.{{cite web|url=http://www.motion-capture-system.com/resources/history.html|title=Motion CaptureResources - History|publisher=motion-capture-system.com|accessdate=2012-02-17}} ===2010s=== ====2019==== *''[[The Lion King (2019 film)|The Lion King]]'' by [[Jon Favreau]], the first fully CGI "[[Live action]]" movie.https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/behind-screen/is-disneys-new-lion-king-an-animated-film-1054516 ==See also== *[[List of directorial debuts]] *[[Timeline of computer animation in film and television]] == References == {{Reflist}} * Netzley, Patricia D. ''Encyclopedia of Movie Special Effects''. Checkmark Books, 2001. [[Category:History of film]] [[Category:Lists of firsts|Cinema]]

/* Metaphor in analytic philosophy */
revision.text:
'''[[Metaphor]]''', the description of one thing as something else, has become of interest in recent decades to both [[analytic philosophy]] and [[continental philosophy]], but for different reasons.
== Metaphor in analytic philosophy == In the Anglo-American tradition of [[analytic philosophy]] (in particular, in the [[philosophy of language]]), [[metaphor]] has attracted interest because it does not conform to accepted [[truth-conditional semantics]], the conditions which determine whether or not a statement is true. Taken literally, the statement "Juliet is the sun" (from ''[[Romeo and Juliet]]'') is false, if not nonsensical, yet, taken metaphorically, it is meaningful and may be true, but in a sense which is far from clear. The comparison theory of metaphor asserts that one can express the [[truth value]] of a metaphor by listing all the respects in which the two terms are alike or similar; for example: Juliet is ''like'' the sun because she shares with it qualities such as radiance, brilliance, the fact that she makes the day and that she gets up every morning. However, this results in re-casting metaphor as [[simile]]. Because it can only explain the truth of metaphor by in effect losing metaphor, the comparison theory is rarely defended.
In contrast, two leading theorists emphasize the fact that [[truth conditions]] cannot be specified for a metaphor. [[Max Black]] maintains that metaphors are too open-ended to be able to function as [[referring expression]]s, and so cannot be expressions which have truth conditions {{Harv |Black|1962}}. If metaphors are used in contexts where precise terminology is expected (for example, in a scientific theory), then their role, Black argues, is purely [[heuristic]], that is, they are means to an end or ways of assisting understanding, rather than being terms which can be tested for truth or falsity {{Harv |Black|1962| p= 37}}. [[Donald Davidson (philosopher)|Donald Davidson]] also thinks it a mistake to look for the truth conditions of a metaphor, since, in his words, "much of what we are caused to notice [in a metaphor] is not propositional in character", that is to say, metaphor is a prompt to thought which cannot be reduced to or contained by a series of [[truth conditions]] {{Harv |Davidson|1984| p= 263}}. What metaphor does, Davidson maintains, is make us see one thing as something else by "making [a] literal statement that inspires or prompts the insight" {{Harv |Davidson|1984| p= 263}}. Seeing one thing as something else is not the recognition of some truth or fact, and so "the attempt to give literal expression to the content of the metaphor is simply misguided".{{Harv |Davidson|1984| p= 263}}
Max Black develops the idea that metaphor actually creates insight or new meaning {{Harv |Black|1979}}. His interactionist theory asserts that at the heart of a metaphor is the interaction between its two subject terms, where the interaction provides the condition for a meaning which neither of the subject terms possesses independently of the metaphorical context. The primary [[subject (grammar)|subject]] in a metaphor, he claims, is coloured by a set of "associated implications" normally predicated of the secondary [[subject (grammar)|subject]] {{Harv |Black|1979| p= 28}}. From the number of possible meanings which could result, the primary subject sieves the qualities predicable of the secondary subject, letting through only those that fit. The interaction, as a process, brings into being what Black terms an "[[Logical implication|implication]]-complex", a system of associated implications shared by the linguistic community as well as an impulse of free meaning, free in that it is meaning which was unavailable prior to the metaphor's introduction.{{Harv |Black|1979| p= 28}}
In a different, naturalist, approach, some English-speaking philosophers close to [[cognitive science]], such as [[George Lakoff | Lakoff]], have made metaphor the central aspect of human rationality.
== Metaphor in continental philosophy == Whereas analytic philosophy examines metaphor within the philosophy of language, [[continental philosophy]] assigns much wider significance to metaphor. This is because the climate within continental thought has been more favourable to the propagation of new branches of enquiry from nineteenth century German philosophy. Although [[Immanuel Kant|Kant]] and [[Hegel]] sit quite happily on both analytic and continental curricula, it is only the latter which has seriously addressed the need to rethink how the world appears to us and how it is made manifest to us in the light of their [[metaphysics]]. Metaphor has proven to be extremely important for this rethinking because it is the process of conceptual borrowing or reassignment which revises our perception of the world.
The major shift which occurs in [[Kantian]] continental philosophy, according to Cazeaux, is the departure 'from dualistic thought, i.e. thinking which remains within the boundaries created by oppositions, such as mind—body and subjective—objective' {{Harv |Cazeaux|2007| p=4}}. The turn away from dualistic thought is made by Kant on account of his representing experience as the subjective determination of an objective world, thereby placing in a relationship terms which normally stand as opposites in a dualism. As a result of this shift, without conventional dualisms to fall back upon, the process of conceptual borrowing and cross-referral presented by metaphor becomes central as the means by which the textures and complexities of experience can be articulated. Theses to this effect, but with significant differences, can be found in [[Kierkegaard]], [[Nietzsche]], [[Heidegger]], [[Merleau-Ponty]], [[Bachelard]], [[Paul Ricoeur]], and [[Derrida]].
To give two examples. According to [[Nietzsche]], we are in metaphor or we are metaphor: our being is not derived from a [[Platonism|Platonic]], eternal [[essence]] or from a [[René Descartes|Cartesian]] thinking substance but (in as much as there is a way of being we can call ours) is emergent from tensional interactions between competing drives or perspectives {{Harv |Nietzsche|2000}}. We customarily hold truth to be a relation of correspondence between knowledge and reality but, Nietzsche declares, it is in fact ‘a movable host of metaphors, metonymies, and anthropomorphisms’ due to the fundamentally metaphorical nature of concept-formation, a series of creative leaps from nerve [[Stimulus (physiology)|stimulus]] to retinal image (first metaphor) to sound as signifier (second metaphor) {{Harv |Nietzsche|2000| p=55}}. Our categories, and the judgments we form with them, can never correspond to things in themselves because they are formed through a series of transformations which ensures that ‘there is no [[causality]], no correctness, and no expression’ connecting the first stage (the stimulus) with the last (the concept) {{Harv |Nietzsche|2000| p=58}}.
For [[Paul Ricoeur|Ricoeur]], metaphor is also ‘living’ – hence the title of his book, ''La Métaphore vive'' {{Harv |Ricoeur|1975}} (translated into English as ''The Rule of Metaphor'' {{Harv |Ricoeur|1977}}) – but in a different sense from Nietzsche . Metaphor is living, Ricoeur claims, in that it is the principle which revives our [[perception]] of the world and through which we become aware of our creative capacity for seeing the world anew. This process, he thinks, is both paradoxical and Kantian in nature: paradoxical in that the creative combination of terms in a metaphor nevertheless produces meaning which has the character of a discovery (how can something be both a creation and a discovery?), and Kantian because the paradox mirrors Kant’s theory of experience in which the subjective application of concepts nevertheless yields perception of an objective world. The tension between the subjective, creative and the objective, discovery aspects of a metaphor, Ricoeur argues, proceeds ‘from the very structures of the mind, which it is the task of [Kant’s] transcendental philosophy to articulate’ {{Harv |Ricoeur|1977| p=300}}. Unfortunately, the part of Kant’s philosophy which Ricoeur appeals to is highly problematic: the [[Schema (Kant)|schema]] or schematism, the operation which Kant dismisses as ‘an art concealed in the depths of the human soul' {{Harv |Kant|1929| p=183, A141, B180-81}}. Ricoeur’s Kantianism is considered at length by Cazeaux {{Harv |Cazeaux|2007}} and Stellardi {{Harv |Stellardi|2000}}, with the former providing an account of how the schematism might afford a coherent explanation of metaphor.
Another reason for the attention paid by continental philosophy to metaphor is the questioning of boundaries – between subject areas and between the wider concepts of [[ethics]], [[epistemology]] and [[aesthetics]] – which has occurred within [[postmodernism]]. Principal concerns in these debates are the status of knowledge and the way in which the concepts of [[truth]] and objectivity are understood. Philosophy has been under attack on this score with its history of ‘universal truths’, e.g. [[Descartes]]’s cogito, [[Immanuel Kant|Kant]]’s table of categories, and [[Hegel]]’s Absolute Consciousness. The main arguments against this universalism invoke metaphor on two related accounts: (1) the fact that key epistemological concepts have metaphors at their root, for example, “mirroring”, “[[Communication|correspondence]]”, “[[sense data]]”, is taken as evidence of the contingent, communal, subjective basis of knowledge, and (2) because metaphor (as a form of dislocated or dislocating predication) works by testing the appropriate with the inappropriate, it is seen as a means of challenging the boundaries whereby one subject defines itself in relation to another.

{{unreferenced|date=March 2012}} [[File:Otakar Hostinsky Vilimek.jpg|thumb|Otakar Hostinský.]] '''Otakar Hostinský''' (2 January 1847, [[Martiněves]] (near [[Litoměřice]]) – 19 January 1910, [[Prague]]) was a [[Czech people|Czech]] historian, [[musicologist]], and professor of [[musical aesthetics]]. He is known primarily for his support of [[composer]] [[Bedřich Smetana]] and his contributions to Czech aesthetic theory, which influenced many cultural figures in early twentieth-century Prague, including [[Zdeněk Nejedlý]], [[Otakar Zich]], and [[Vladimír Helfert]]. He also wrote the [[opera]] [[libretto]]s to [[Zdeněk Fibich]]'s masterpiece, ''[[The Bride of Messina (opera)|The Bride of Messina]]'', and [[Josef Rozkosný]]'s ''Cinderella''. ==Biography== {{Empty section|date=July 2010}} ==Selected writings== (German titles given in the original; Czech titles translated into English) ''Art and Nationality'', 1869
''Wagnerianism and Czech National Identity'', 1870
''On "Program" Music'', 1873
''Das Musikalisch-Schöne und das Gesamtkunstwerk vom Standpunkte der formalen Aesthetik'', 1877
''On the Contemporary State and Direction of Czech Music'', 1880
''On Czech Musical Declamation'', 1882
''On Melodrama'', 1885
''A Brief Overview of the History of Music'', 1885
''On Artistic Realism'', 1890
''Herbarts Aesthetik'', 1891
''Volkslied und Tanz der Slaven'', 1893
''On Progress in Art'', 1894
''On Folksong'', 1897
''On Experimental Aesthetics'', 1900
''B. Smetana and his Struggle for Modern Czech Music'', 1901
''On the Socialization of Art'', 1903
''Art and Society'', 1907
''Czech Music, 1864-1904'', 1909 ==References== {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hostinsky, Otakar}} [[Category:1847 births]] [[Category:1910 deaths]] [[Category:People from Litoměřice District]] [[Category:Czech musicologists]] [[Category:Czech opera librettists]] [[Category:Czech male writers]] [[Category:Czech historians]] [[Category:Czech philosophers]]

'''Petri Mór''' (July 11, 1863 in [[Tăşnad]] – March 2, 1945 in [[Budapest]]) was a teacher, school inspector and author in [[Transylvania]].
His masterwork is ''Szilágy vármegye monographiája'' (I-IV, Budapest, 1901–1904).
== Works ==
* Szilágy vármegye monographiája (I-VI., Budapest, 1901–1904) * Magyar szonettek (Budapest, 1933) * Vándor a kertajtónál (versek, Budapest, 1936) * Naplemente fáklyalángja (versek, Budapest, 1941) * Várballadák és modern balladák (Budapest, 1943) * A boldogság triolettjei (versek, Budapest, 1943)
== Place names ==

'''Pilip Ballach Ó Duibhgeannáin''' ([[floruit|''fl.'']] 1579–1590) was an Irish historian.
A member of the [[Clan Ó Duibhgeannáin]] and a hereditary historian, Pilip was a resident of Cloonybrien, [[County Roscommon]]. With [[Brian na Carriag MacDermot]] and others he compiled the [[Annals of Lough Cé]] and various other manuscripts, including [[Miscellanea Historica Hibernica]]
[[Paul Walsh (priest)|Paul Walsh]] suggested that he was a son of Fer Caogad mac Ferghal Ó Duibhgeannáin, who died at Cloonybried in 1581.
==Sources==
* ''Irish Medieval Learning'', by [[Fr. Paul Walsh]], 1918, pp. 18–19. * ''Rudimenta Physionomiae'', by [[Gearóid mac Niocaill]], in ''Celtica'' vi (1963), pp. 271–77. * ''A world of wonders:marvels and prodigies in the diocese of [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Elphin|Elphin]], 1588'', pp. 134–54, in ''Stories from Gaelic Ireland:Microhistories from the sixteenth-century Irish annals'', by [[Bernadette Cunningham]] and [[Raymond Gillespie]], Four Courts Press, [[Dublin]], 2003, {{ISBN|1-85182-747-1}}.
