{{Infobox terrorist attack |title =Schoenau ultimatum |image = |caption = |location = [[Marchegg]], [[Austria]] |target = [[Jew]]ish passengers |date= September 28-29, 1973 |time = |timezone = [[UTC]]+1 |type = [[Hostage-taking]] |fatalities = 0 |perps = [[As-Sa'iqa]] |motive = [[Israeli–Palestinian conflict]] }} The '''Schoenau ultimatum''' was a [[hostage-taking]] incident in [[Marchegg]], [[Austria]] by the Palestinian militant group [[As-Sa'iqa]]. At the time Vienna was a transit point for [[Russian Jews]], the largest population of [[Jews]] remaining in Europe. The Schoenau ultimatum focused attention away from Egyptian and Syrian military build-up and their planned attack that would come to be known as the [[Yom Kippur War]].
==Background== The Israeli government had long encouraged European Jewish refugees to immigrate to [[Israel]]. After many of the Jews displaced by the [[Holocaust]] had emigrated to Israel, the Russian Jewish population, the last source of [[Ashkenazi Jews]], who were facing increasing oppression within the [[Soviet Union]], became an important population encouraged to emigrate to Israel.<ref name="Hughes-Wilson p. 248">{{Harvnb|Hughes-Wilson|1999|p=248}}</ref> In the wake of the [[Six-Day War]] in 1967, the Soviet Union broke off diplomatic relations with Israel. This stirred up [[Zionist]] feelings among some Soviet Jews, the majority of whom were [[cultural assimilation|assimilated]] and [[secularity|non-religious]].
A mass emigration was politically undesirable for the Soviet regime. As increasing numbers of [[Aliyah from the Soviet Union in the 1970s|Soviet Jews applied to emigrate]] to Israel in the period following the Six-Day War, many were [[Refusenik (Soviet Union)|formally refused permission]] to leave. After the [[Dymshits–Kuznetsov hijacking affair]] in 1970 and the crackdown that followed, strong international condemnations caused the Soviet authorities to increase the emigration [[:wikt:quota|quota]]. From 1960 to 1970, only 4,000 people left the Soviet Union; in the following decade, the number rose to 250,000.<ref name="Alekseyeva p. ">{{Harvnb|Alekseyeva|1992|p=}}</ref>
Many of these Jews passed through the transit center located at the [[Schönau an der Triesting|Schönau]] Castle in Austria. The Castle was used by the Austrian government as a transit camp for Russian Jews who had just been permitted to leave Russia prior to emigrating to the West.<ref name="Dank p. ">{{Harvnb|Dank|1984|p=}}</ref>
==Hostage taking==
On September 28, 1973, 3 to 7{{#tag:ref|Sources give different number of the amount of hostages taken|group="A"}} Jewish emigrants were taken hostage, among them a 73-year-old man, an ailing woman and a three-year-old child, on a train at the Austria-[[Czechoslovakia]]n border by a Syrian-based [[Palestinian people|Palestinian Arab]] militant group, [[As-Sa'iqa]].<ref name="Dank p. "/><ref name="Avner p. ">{{Harvnb|Avner|2011|p=}}</ref> In addition to demanding a free passage to an Arab country, they gave the Austrian government an ultimatum to close the Schönau transit center or they would execute the hostages. [[Chancellor of Austria|Austrian Chancellor]] [[Bruno Kreisky]] gave in to the demands and closed the Jewish Agency's transit facility.
The incident captured the attention of Israeli media and became a ''[[cause célèbre]]''.<ref name="Hughes-Wilson p. 248"/> Israeli Prime Minister Golda Meir diverted her return flight from the [[Council of Europe]] to try and convince Kreisky to not give in to the demands. Kreisky refused to change his position, and Meir returned to Israel infuriated.<ref name="Avner p. 219">{{Harvnb|Avner|2010|p=219}}</ref> With the center closed, the militants were flown to Libya.<ref name="Austria Press Agency p. "/>
==Result== The entire incident captured the attention of the Israeli government when it should have been focusing on Egyptian and Syrian military build-up. The Schoenau ultimatum is seen as one of the causes of the massive military intelligence blunder of the Israeli Intelligence in not foreseeing the surprise attack of the [[Yom Kippur War]].<ref name="Hughes-Wilson p. 248">{{Harvnb|Hughes-Wilson|1999|p=248}}</ref><ref name="Dank p. "/>
In December 1973, the Schönau Castle Jewish center was closed for good and was replaced by the Wöllersdorf National Association of the Red Cross of Lower Austria for refugees.<ref name="Austria Press Agency p. ">{{Harvnb|Austria Press Agency|2011|p=}}</ref>
==Annotations== {{Reflist|group="A"}}

[[File:Shell Grotto, Margate, Kent 14 - 2011.09.17.jpg|thumb|Part of the Shell Grotto in Margate]] A '''shell grotto''' is a type of [[folly]], a [[grotto]] decorated with [[sea shell]]s.
==History== The shell grotto was a popular feature of British country house in the 17th and 18th centuries. It arose from the influence of the [[Rococo style]] (which used swirling motifs similar to sea shells)<ref name=HJ>Hazelle Jackson, ''Shell Houses and Grottoes'' ( 2001) {{ISBN|9780747805229}} ([http://www.londongardenstrust.org/features/grotto.htm abstract])</ref> and mimicry of architectural features from the [[Italian renaissance]] (themselves copies from Classical times). The idea of a grotto was originally a means to enhance a dank [[undercroft]], or provide an antechamber before a ''[[piano nobile]]'', but later became a garden feature independent of the house. Early grottos were mainly of the shell grotto type, mimicking a sea-cave, or in the form of a [[nymphaeum]]; later there was a move towards more naturalistic cave-like grottoes.<ref name=HJ/>
The first recorded shell grotto in England was at [[Whitehall Palace]]; [[James VI and I|James I]] had it built in the undercroft of the [[Banqueting House, Whitehall|Banqueting House]] in 1624, but it hasn't survived. Two years later the [[Duke of Bedford]] had a shell room built at [[Woburn Abbey]], featuring shell mosaics and carved stone. This, and another at [[Skipton Castle]], built in 1627, are the only surviving examples from the 17th century.<ref name=HJ/>
Shell grottoes were an expensive luxury: The grotto at [[Oatlands Park]] cost £25,000 in 1781 and took 11 years to build; and at [[Fisherwick|Fisherwick Park]] the [[Marquess of Donegall]] spent £10,000 on shells alone in 1789.<ref name=Tat>[https://www.tatler.com/article/the-poshest-grottoes ''The 4 poshest garden grottoes''] [[Tatler]] 27 July 2015; retrieved 30 July 2018</ref> [[Shell Grotto, Margate|The Grotto]] at [[Margate]] has 2000 square feet of mosaic, using some 4.6 million shells.
By the end of the 18th century fashion had moved on to more naturalistic cave-like structures, before falling out of favour altogether. Many were demolished or have fallen into disrepair, but some 200 grottos of all types are known to have survived in some form in the UK.<ref name=HJ/>
==Examples== *[[Shell Grotto, Margate]], an example in Margate, Kent, England *[[Shell Grotto, Pontypool]], another in Pontypool, Wales *[[Scott's Grotto]], a shell grotto in Ware, Hertfordshire, England *The Shell Room at [[Woburn Abbey]], the earliest surviving 17th-century shell grotto<ref name=WA>[http://www.woburnabbey.co.uk/abbey/abbey-today/must-sees/ ''The Grotto''] at woburnabbey.co.uk</ref> *The east tower of [[Skipton Castle]]'s gatehouse contains a 17th-century shell grotto *[[Shell Grotto, Nienoord]], a treasury at the Nienoord estate in [[Leek, Netherlands|Leek]], Netherlands *The Shell Grotto at [[Château de Vendeuvre#The_Shell_Grotto|Château de Vendeuvre]] *The Shell-lined grotto at [[Goldney Hall]], Bristol, England *The Shell Grotto at [[Endsleigh Cottage#Grounds|Endsleigh Cottage]], England * [[Headley-Whitney Museum]], in Lexington, Kentucky, US where a former three car garage was transformed into a shell grotto * The Shell House in Terrington, N Yorkshire UK * The former [[Paua House]] in [[Bluff, New Zealand]], now partly re-created at [[Canterbury Museum, Christchurch]] * Shell-covered gardening sheds in [[Grosvenor Gardens, London]]
==See also== * [[Shellcraft]]

[[File:Portrait of Thomas Martin Lindsay.jpg|thumb|T. M. Lindsay.]] '''Thomas Martin Lindsay''' [[Doctor of Divinity|DD]] [[FRSE]] (1843–1914) was a [[Scottish people|Scottish]] historian, professor and principal of the [[Trinity College, Glasgow|Free Church College, Glasgow]]. He was a prolific writer of church history and in authorship he is often referred to as '''Thomas M. Lindsay'''.
He wrote chiefly on [[church history]], his major works including ''Luther and the German Reformation'' (1900), and ''A History of the Reformation in Europe'' (1906–1907).
==Life== He was born on 18 October 1843 in [[Lesmahagow]]<ref>{{cite book|title=Biographical Index of Former Fellows of the Royal Society of Edinburgh 1783 – 2002|date=July 2006|publisher=The Royal Society of Edinburgh|isbn=0 902 198 84 X|url=https://www.royalsoced.org.uk/cms/files/fellows/biographical_index/fells_indexp2.pdf}}</ref> in [[Lanarkshire]], the eldest son of Rev. Alexander Lindsay, and his wife, Susan Irvine Martin. He was educated in Lesmahagow.
Lindsay studied divinity at the [[University of Glasgow]] and then at the [[University of Edinburgh]]. In 1869 he entered the ministry of the [[Free Church of Scotland (1843–1900)|Free Church of Scotland]], and in 1872 was appointed Professor of Church History at the [[Trinity College, Glasgow|Free Church College, Glasgow]]. He was then living at "Thornliebank" on Ann Street in the [[Hillhead]] district<ref>Glasgow Post Office Directory 1875</ref> when he married Anna Dunlop. [[Anna Lindsay (Scotland)|Anna Lindsay]] had just been a student in Edinburgh.<ref name=anna/>
Lindsay took up the position of Principal of the College in 1902.<ref name=odnb>'Lindsay, Thomas Martin (1843–1914), historian' in [[Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]] (Oxford University Press, 2007)</ref> He then moved to the more affluent address of 37 Westbourne Gardens in [[Kelvinside]],<ref>Glasgow Post Office Directory 1903</ref> an attractive three-storey and basement Victorian terraced house.
Lindsay unsuccessfully supported [[William Robertson Smith]] in a trial for [[heresy]] between 1877 and 1881 which resulted in Smith's losing his position at the [[Christ's College, Aberdeen|Aberdeen Free Church College]].<ref name=odnb/> He died in Glasgow on 6 December 1912.<ref>{{cite book|title=Biographical Index of Former Fellows of the Royal Society of Edinburgh 1783 – 2002|date=July 2006|publisher=The Royal Society of Edinburgh|isbn=0 902 198 84 X|url=https://www.royalsoced.org.uk/cms/files/fellows/biographical_index/fells_indexp2.pdf}}</ref>
==Publications== *''The Critical Movement in the Free Church of Scotland'' (1879) *''The Reformation'' (1882) *''Luther and the German Reformation'' (1900) *''The Church and the Ministry in the Early Centuries'' (1902) *''The New Testament'' (1906) *''A History of the Reformation in Europe'' (two volumes, 1906 and 1907). *''An Oxford Bookseller in 1520'' (1907) *''Englishmen and the Classical Renaissance'' (1909)
He was a contributor to ''[[Encyclopædia Britannica]]'' and to the [[the Cambridge Modern History|Cambridge Modern History]].<ref name=odnb/>
==Family== Lindsay married Anna Dunlop. The [[Glasgow Association for the Higher Education of Women]] was started at the suggestion of Mrs [[Jean Campbell]] in 1868.<ref name="jean">{{Cite journal|last=Myers|first=Christine D.|date=2001-12-01|title=The Glasgow Association for the Higher Education of Women, 1878 to 1883|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1540-6563.2001.tb01470.x/abstract|journal=Historian|language=en|volume=63|issue=2|pages=357–371|doi=10.1111/j.1540-6563.2001.tb01470.x|issn=1540-6563}}</ref> Anna Lindsay was one of its founders. Lindsay's name was said to be synonymous with the women's movement in Scotland.<ref name=anna>K. D. Reynolds, ‘Lindsay, Anna (1845–1903)’, Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Oxford University Press, 2004 [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/56265, accessed 14 Oct 2017]</ref> Their children included [[Sandie Lindsay, 1st Baron Lindsay of Birker|Alexander Lindsay, 1st Baron Lindsay of Birker]], Professor of Moral Philosophy in the [[University of Glasgow]], [[Master of Balliol College]], and [[Vice-Chancellor]] of the [[University of Oxford]].<ref>''[http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/34537?docPos=1 Lindsay, Alexander Dunlop, 1st Baron Lindsay of Birker]'', in [[Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]] at oxforddnb.com(subscription site), accessed 20 June 2013</ref>
==See also== *[[s:Author:Thomas Martin Lindsay|Thomas Martin Lindsay]] at [[Wikisource]]
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{wikiquote}} *[https://www.bbc.co.uk/arts/yourpaintings/paintings/principal-thomas-martin-lindsay-18431914 Thomas Martin Lindsay] portrait by [[George Fiddes Watt]] at bbc.co.uk
{{Authority control}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2017}}

[[File:Iberia_300BC-en.svg|thumb|right|350px|The Iberian Peninsula in the 3rd Century BC, the Varduli are in the northern region, close to the Pyrenees, in a Celt-Aquitanian "mixed" area.]]
The '''Varduli''' were a pre-[[Ancient Rome|Roman]] tribe<ref>John James Van Nostrand Jr, ''The reorganization of Spain by Augustus" ''University of California Publications in History'' '''4''', 1916:122ff</ref> settled in the north of the [[Iberian Peninsula]], in what today is the eastern region of the autonomous community of the [[Basque Country (autonomous community)|Basque Country]] and western [[Navarre]], in northern [[Spain]]. Their historical territory corresponds with current [[Basque language|Basque]]-speaking areas, however it is debated whether the Varduli were actually [[Aquitani]]ans, related to the [[Vascones]],<ref name="vascones">[http://www.euskomedia.org/PDFAnlt/congresos/07217221.pdf ''Localización de algunas ciudades várdulas citadas por Mela y Ptolomeo'' Ildefonso Gurruchaga]</ref> or if they were [[Celts]], related to tribes such as the [[Cantabri]] and [[Celtiberians]]<ref name="celtiberians">[http://www.euskara.it/dipartimento-basco-uni-upter/HITZALDIAK%20-%20CONFERENZE/MERTXE___URTEAGA.pdf ''El puerto romano de Irun'' Mercedes Urteaga]</ref> and which later underwent [[Late Basquisation|Basquisation]].<ref name="ethnic map">[http://www.arkeotavira.com/Mapas/Iberia/Populi.htm Ethnic map of the Iberian Peninsula after the Second Punic War]</ref>
== Etymology ==
Their ethnonym ''Varduli'' is connected with an area that is referred to in documents from the early [[Middle Ages]] as [[Bardulia]], which is identified as the cradle of [[Old Castile]]. [[Julio Caro Baroja]], a Spanish anthropologist and linguist declared on his works that the term ''Varduli'' does not have a [[Basque language|Basque]] origin.<ref>Caro Baroja, Julio. ''Los pueblos de España'', 1976.</ref>
== History ==
The Varduli are mentioned for the first time during [[Ancient Rome|Roman]] times, by [[Strabo]], who called them ''Bardyetai'', and placed them in the Basque coast, between the [[Cantabri]] and [[Vascones]]; they are also mentioned by the geographer [[Ptolemy]], who placed them roughly in present-day [[Gipuzkoa]], and by Roman historians, notably [[Pliny the Elder]] in his ''[[Natural History (Pliny)|Naturalis Historia]]'',<ref>"In Cluniensem conventum Varduli ducunt populos xiiii" (Pliny iii.26); "A Pyranaeo per oceanum Vasconum saltus, Olarso, Vardulorum oppida..." iv.110..</ref> where he reported that ''Amanum Portus'' (Roman name: ''Flaviobriga''), present-day [[Castro Urdiales]], was a Varduli city. The Roman geographer [[Pomponius Mela]] located them also in the coast, west of the Vascones and east of the [[Caristii]]. This lack of agreement about their exact position may have been caused by the continuous movement of the tribes of the northern Iberian Peninsula during events such as the [[Cantabrian Wars]]. The first census of the Varduli population took place under the orders of [[Augustus]].<ref>''[[Corpus Inscriptionum Latinarum|CIL]]'' vi, 1463, noted by Van Nostrand 1916:123.</ref>
According to [[Pliny the Elder]], the main Varduli city was ''Olarso'',{{Citation needed|date=August 2012}} which is believed to be present-day [[Uharte-Arakil]] ([[Navarre]]). In 114 BC, [[Gaius Marius]] had a personal guard made by Varduli people, who were called Barduaioí slaves in [[Rome]]. By the year 44, and according to Pomponius Mela, the Varduli inhabited lands close to the [[Pyrenees]] and composed a united society. The defeat of the [[Cantabri]] against Augustus did not have any effect on the Varduli, as they had not joined the wars.
The Varduli served in [[Cohort (military unit)|cohort]]s in the province of [[Britannia]]: Varduli are mentioned in an inscription on a Roman altar at Rochester, (Roman Bremenium) and at [[Milecastle 19]] along [[Hadrian's Wall]] an altar inscription made by members of the First Cohort of Varduli, cavalrymen, is one of the few dedications to the [[Matres|''Matres'', or mother goddesses]], found in Roman Britain. The First Cohort of Varduli are also mentioned in inscriptions at the [[Antonine Wall]], [[Longovicium]] in Durham, [[Bremenium]] and [[Corstopitum]] in Northumberland and on the [[Dere Street]] in Cappuck in the Scottish Borders.<ref name=rbo>{{cite web|title=BREMENIVM Roman Fort & Marching Camps|url=http://www.roman-britain.org/places/bremenium.htm|publisher=Roman Britain Organisation|accessdate=11 March 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120414183611/http://www.roman-britain.org/places/bremenium.htm|archive-date=14 April 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
As with the [[Caristii]], it is discussed whether the Varduli were an [[Aquitani]]an tribe or a [[Celts|Celt]] one, related to the [[Cantabri]] and [[Celtiberians]]. Their place-names were clearly of Indo-European origin (probably [[Proto-Celtic language]]), as ''Uxama'' (comes from ''Ups Ama'', meaning "the highest"), ''Deobriga'' (comes from ''Deiuo-Briga'', meaning "holy hill"), ''Tullonium'' (comes from ''Tullo'', meaning "valley"), among others. As with the Caristii, not a single toponym related to the [[Aquitanian language|Aquitanian]]-[[Proto-Basque language|Basque languages]] has been found, further proving the theory of their Celtic origin and possible [[late Basquisation]].<ref name="vascones" /><ref name="celtiberians" /><ref name="ethnic map" /> However, but for a few exceptions (''Deba'', ''[[Zegama]]'', ''Arakama'') present-day place-names show a clear prevalence of the Basque linguistic element (sometimes mixed with Latin and Romance lexical roots).
The last reference to the Varduli appears on a chronicle from [[Hydatius]], where he narrates the devastations that suffered the [[Heruli]] when they attacked in the year 400 the [[Bay of Biscay|Cantabrian coast]] and again in 456 after attacking [[Bardulia]].
{{quote|Ad sedes propias redeuntes, Cantabriarum et Vardaliarum loca maritima crudelissime deproedatio sunt.|Fontes Hispaniae Antiquae, IX, p. 74}} Later in the next century, Saxons established on the Bordeaux estuary also were known to raid along the coast.
It is believed by some that the Varduli suffered a [[Late Basquisation|Basquisation]] as a result of the continuous progress of the [[Vascones]] on their territory. They are not mentioned again in the [[Early Middle Ages]] and their place appeared the precursors of the province of [[Gipuzkoa]]. Some authors<ref>http://www.euskomedia.org/PDFAnlt/congresos/07217221.pdf</ref> deducted, following Classic documents, the existence of some ethnic affinity, collaboration, or political union between the [[Caristii]], the [[Autrigones]] and the Varduli, tribes who later would all be grouped under the name ''Varduli'', this would explain all the later events on this region, for example, why once the Caristii and Varduli were moved out of their original territories by the [[Vascones]] in the Early Middle Ages, the Caristii and Autrigones lost their names and were grouped together with the Varduli over the territory of the Autrigones who took refuge in their coastal areas behind the mountains from the Islamic military depredations from the Al-andalus new powers down the Ebro, which passed to be made after a century of resettlement into the Meseta plains as a frontier march or county of the Kingdom of [[Kingdom of Asturias|Asturias]] in the middle years of the 8th century, the original one called Castile. The union, whichever the causes, between Varduli, Caristii and Autrigones on a unique territory would later create the blur County of Bardulia, mentioned as part of the Crown of Castile.
The coat of arms of the [[Basque Country (autonomous community)|Basque]] province of [[Gipuzkoa]] reads ''"Fidelissima Bardulia, Nunquam Superata"'',<ref>[http://w390w.gipuzkoa.net/WAS/CORP/DJGPortalWEB/territorio_historico_de_gipuzkoa.jsp?id=02&idioma=es Juntas Generales de Gipuzkoa - Escudo y bandera]</ref> meaning "Loyal Bardulia, never conquered".

蕭一山 |imagesize = 200px |birth_date={{birth date|1902|5|7|df=y}} |birth_place=[[Xuzhou|Tongshan]], [[Jiangsu]], [[Qing China]] |ancestry= |death_date={{death date|1978|7|4|df=y}} |death_place=[[Taipei]], [[Taiwan]] |occupation = historian |parents= |relations= |alma_mater= [[Peking University]] }} '''Xiao Yishan''' (蕭一山, May 7, 1902 – July 4, 1978) was a modern Chinese historian. He entered [[Peking University]] in 1921, learned from the prominent scholar [[Liang Qichao]]. He later taught history of [[Qing Dynasty]] at [[Tsinghua University]], [[Henan University]], [[Northeastern University (China)|Northeastern University]] and [[Northwest University (China)|Northwest University]]. In winter 1948, Xiao moved to [[Taiwan]]. ''General History of the Qing Dynasty'' (《清代通史》) is his masterpiece, in that book he promoted a historical view of nationalism.{{cite web |url=http://news.163.com/06/0417/04/2ESP2J6E00011229.html |title=萧一山：清史研究第一人 |author=中国青年报 |publisher=163.com |date=2006-04-17 |accessdate=2014-08-03}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Xiao, Yishan}} [[Category:Republic of China historians]] [[Category:Peking University alumni]] [[Category:Tsinghua University faculty]] [[Category:Henan University faculty]] [[Category:Northeastern University (China) faculty]] [[Category:Writers from Xuzhou]] [[Category:National Taiwan University faculty]] [[Category:1902 births]] [[Category:1978 deaths]] [[Category:20th-century historians]] [[Category:Educators from Xuzhou]] [[Category:Historians from Jiangsu]]
